description:
Fomitopsis serialis is a species of wood-decay fungus that belongs to the family Fomitopsidaceae. It is a perennial, polypore fungus that typically grows on the dead or dying wood of various coniferous tree species, such as spruce, fir, and pine.

The fungus produces a flat, shelf-like fruiting body that can range in color from white to reddish-brown. The upper surface of the fruiting body is usually smooth and slightly shiny, while the pore surface on the underside is white to pale yellow. The pores are small and circular, and the context (internal tissue) of the fruiting body is dense and fibrous.

Fomitopsis serialis is known to cause a type of wood rot called white rot, in which the fungus decomposes the lignin and cellulose components of the wood, leaving behind a white, spongy material. This wood-decay process can weaken and ultimately destroy the structural integrity of the affected trees, making them more susceptible to windthrow or other forms of damage.

The fungus is widely distributed in temperate and boreal forest regions of the Northern Hemisphere, where it plays an important role in the decomposition of dead and dying trees, contributing to the nutrient cycling and ecosystem dynamics of these forest habitats.
